sen.j: 藤原 宗輔（ふじわら の むねすけ、承暦元年（1077年）-応保2年1月30日 (旧暦)（1162年2月15日））は、平安時代後期の公卿（従一位太政大臣）。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Munesuke (1077 -February 15, 1162) was a noble (Juichii (Junior First Rank), Daijodaijin (Grand Minister of State) who lived in the late Heian Period.

sen.j: 宗輔は漢籍や有職故実に通じた真面目な人物であったが、のんびりとしていてそそっかしい人物であったと伝えられている。
sen.e: Reportedly, Munesuke was a honest person who was well versed in kanseki (books in classical Chinese) and yosoku kojitsu (well-versed in usages or practices of the court or military households (practices)), but, at the same time, he was carefree and hasty.

sen.j: 1096年に父が52歳の若さで死去した際には、まだ五位蔵人という低い官職であり、側近として仕えまた笛を通じた友人でもあった堀河天皇が早世するなどの不幸もあり、46歳でやっと参議に列するような有様であった。
sen.e: When his father died young in 1096 at the age of fifty-two, his rank was as low as goi kurodo (chamberlain with the fifth rank) and partly because of hard luck to him that the Emperor Horikawa, to whom he served as a close aide and who was his friend through flute, died young, he could join the Sangi (Royal Advisor) only at the age of forty-six.

sen.j: 1129年の除目では、宗輔が源師頼の任官された職務を誤って書き写した公文書を作成してしまい、除目のやり直しが行われた事が伝えられている（ちなみに師頼は宗輔の母方の伯父にあたる）。
sen.e: Reportedly, on the occasion of jimoku (ceremony for appointment of court officials) in 1129, he made a document in which the position to which MINAMOTO no Moroyori was appointed was erroneously transcribed and the jimoku was held again. (By the way, Moroyori was Munesuke's maternal uncle.)

sen.e: With respect to music, he was good at playing a flute and a koto (zither-like Japanese musical instrument) and, reportedly, he himself told "I am not afraid of my death, but it is a problem that I cannot play a flute."

sen.j: また、娘・若御前も父に勝るとも劣らない才能を持ち（「若御前」とは、鳥羽法皇が彼女の曲を聞くために男装をさせて院の御所に上げさせた事に由来していると言う）、後に当代随一の音楽家として名を残した藤原師長（藤原頼長の子、後の太政大臣）の筝もこの親子から習ったものであると伝えられている。
sen.e: His daughter, who was called Wakagozen (reportedly the name "Wakagozen" was derived from the fact that, in order to hear her koto play, the Cloistered Emperor Toba made her to enter the imperial court wearing men's costume), had a gift that was even better than Munesuke's and, reportedly, FUJIWARA no Moronaga (FUJIWARA no Yorinaga's son, later Daijodaijin), who was called the greatest musician of the day leaned koto play from Munesuke and his daughter.

sen.j: 当時の貴族社会では貴族が自ら草花を育てる事は考えられなかったが、宗輔は自ら菊や牡丹を育てて、藤原頼長や鳥羽法皇ら親しい人々に献上している。
sen.e: It was not conceivable in the aristocratic society at that time that any noble grew flowers with own hands, but Munesuke grew chrysanthemum and tree peony and donated them to close friends such as FUJIWARA no Yorinaga and the Cloistered Emperor Toba.

sen.e: According to "Kojidan" (Talks of the Past) it had been laughed at by people as "useless matter," but when there was abnormal infestation by bees in the imperial court, only Munesuke coolly held out a loquat, which bees like very much, bees drank its nectar and calmed down.
